keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former President of France (2007–2012), has become the first French ex-president to go to jail, serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.

Sarkozy is not accused of personally receiving the Libyan funds, but of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who facilitated secret campaign financing through contacts with Gaddafi’s intelligence officials.

The case, known as the 'Bygmalion affair,' involves allegations of illegal campaign financing, with Sarkozy convicted of criminal association despite maintaining his innocence and claiming that the actions were done under duress.
Sarkozy has appealed his sentence and is currently in solitary confinement at La Santé prison in Paris, where he is housed in an isolation wing with limited contact and restricted movement.

The case has sparked national controversy and public debate, with President Emmanuel Macron acknowledging the emotional impact of a former president being imprisoned, though emphasizing non-interference in judicial matters.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin has publicly stated his intention to visit Sarkozy in prison, signaling official recognition of the personal and political gravity of the situation.

Sarkozy has denied wrongdoing and continues to maintain that the prosecution is politically motivated and driven by revenge, calling himself an 'innocent man' in a 'France humiliated by a will for revenge'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former President of France (2007–2012), has become the first French ex-president to be imprisoned, serving a five-year sentence for criminal association in the illegal campaign financing case known as the Bygmalion affair. Although he was not personally accused of receiving Libyan money from Muammar Gaddafi, he was convicted for facilitating secret campaign financing through aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who arranged meetings with Gaddafi’s intelligence officials via intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. Sarkozy has maintained his innocence and launched an appeal, claiming the prosecution is politically motivated and driven by revenge. He is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison in Paris, where he has limited contact with others and restricted movement. The case has sparked significant public and political debate, with President Emmanuel Macron acknowledging the emotional impact, and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin agreeing to visit him. France’s highest administrative court will deliver its verdict on the appeal in late November 2025, potentially overturning or affirming the conviction.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
